20101230010017.000|20101230010019.000|TR0|
20101230010019.000|20101230010021.000|TR0|Tonight's stop story, I call it tyranny of 
20101230010021.000|20101230010023.000|TR0|the majority.  Some people call it 
20101230010023.000|20101230010025.000|TR0|filibusters.  I think it's an abuse of 
20101230010025.000|20101230010027.000|TR0|democracy.  It has overtaken the Senate.
20101230010027.000|20101230010029.000|TR0|
20101230010029.000|20101230010031.000|TR0|Take a look at the chart.  We're going to 
20101230010031.000|20101230010033.000|TR0|show you the filibuster used to be used 
20101230010033.000|20101230010035.000|TR0|once in a blue moon, maybe once or twice 
20101230010035.000|20101230010037.000|TR0|every couple of years.  Past couple of 
20101230010037.000|20101230010039.000|TR0|years over 100 times.  What that means 
20101230010039.000|20101230010041.000|TR0|since you need 60 senators to defeat a 
20101230010041.000|20101230010043.000|TR0|filibuster.  Forty-one senators 
20101230010043.000|20101230010045.000|TR0|representing less than 10 percent of the 
20101230010045.000|20101230010047.000|TR0|public can stop democracy.
20101230010047.000|20101230010049.000|TR0|
20101230010049.000|20101230010051.000|TR0|The Constitution told us where you need a 
20101230010051.000|20101230010053.000|TR0|supermajority, Kathleen, ratifying a 
20101230010053.000|20101230010055.000|TR0|treaty, overturning a presidential veto.  
20101230010055.000|20101230010057.000|TR0|To require a supermajority on every piece 
20101230010057.000|20101230010059.000|TR0|of legislation is wrong, contrary to 
20101230010059.000|20101230010101.000|TR0|democracy.
20101230010101.000|20101230010103.000|TR0|
20101230010103.000|20101230010105.000|TR0|You know what?  When Congress comes back 
20101230010105.000|20101230010107.000|TR0|and the Senate comes back next week, I 
20101230010107.000|20101230010109.000|TR0|hope they reform the filibuster, perhaps 
20101230010109.000|20101230010111.000|TR0|even eliminate the filibuster altogether.

20101230010720.000|20101230010722.000|TR0|CAIN:  When the government acts, when it 
20101230010722.000|20101230010724.000|TR0|passes a law, it is an act of 
20101230010724.000|20101230010726.000|TR0|authoritarianism.  George Washington said 
20101230010726.000|20101230010728.000|TR0|it best.  Government is not reason.  It is 
20101230010728.000|20101230010730.000|TR0|not eloquence.  Government is force.  So 
20101230010730.000|20101230010732.000|TR0|the founders, knowing that, put it in 
20101230010732.000|20101230010734.000|TR0|place structural protections to make it 
20101230010734.000|20101230010736.000|TR0|hard to pass law.
20101230010736.000|20101230010738.000|TR0|
20101230010738.000|20101230010740.000|TR0|They gave us three branches of government, 
20101230010740.000|20101230010742.000|TR0|two legislative branches, veto power -- 
20101230010742.000|20101230010744.000|TR0|all of the intention of it being hard to 
20101230010744.000|20101230010746.000|TR0|pass a law.
20101230010746.000|20101230010748.000|TR0|

20101230010750.000|20101230010752.000|TR0|and therefore you agree that government is 
20101230010752.000|20101230010754.000|TR0|usually a force for ill.
20101230010754.000|20101230010756.000|TR0|
20101230010756.000|20101230010758.000|TR0|CAIN:  Right.
20101230010758.000|20101230010800.000|TR0|
20101230010800.000|20101230010802.000|TR0|SPITZER:  That's fine, I disagree with 
20101230010802.000|20101230010804.000|TR0|you.  But the Constitution defined with 
20101230010804.000|20101230010806.000|TR0|great precision when a supermajority 
20101230010806.000|20101230010808.000|TR0|should be required. Overturning a 
20101230010808.000|20101230010810.000|TR0|presidential veto, ratifying a treaty.  
20101230010810.000|20101230010813.000|TR0|Particular circumstances where the 
20101230010813.000|20101230010815.000|TR0|founding fathers -- and there weren't 
20101230010815.000|20101230010817.000|TR0|founding mothers at the time.  Founding 
20101230010817.000|20101230010819.000|TR0|fathers said this is where we need a super 
20101230010819.000|20101230010821.000|TR0|majority and we will dispense.
20101230010821.000|20101230010823.000|TR0|
20101230010823.000|20101230010825.000|TR0|We have now expanded that to the point of 
20101230010825.000|20101230010827.000|TR0|gridlock.  And I think all of us would 
20101230010827.000|20101230010829.000|TR0|agree, gridlock right now is the crisis 
20101230010829.000|20101230010831.000|TR0|we're facing on energy, on education, on 
20101230010831.000|20101230010833.000|TR0|substantive issues where we need 
20101230010833.000|20101230010835.000|TR0|resolution and the filibuster permits 
20101230010835.000|20101230010837.000|TR0|gridlock.
20101230010837.000|20101230010839.000|TR0|
20101230010839.000|20101230010841.000|TR0|Wait, let's get James in.  I think he's 
20101230010841.000|20101230010843.000|TR0|trying to --
20101230010843.000|20101230010845.000|TR0|
20101230010845.000|20101230010847.000|TR0|CARVILLE:  Just want to put it on record.  
20101230010847.000|20101230010849.000|TR0|I went to law school on the GI bill.  I 
20101230010849.000|20101230010851.000|TR0|don't think it's authoritarianism.  I 
20101230010851.000|20101230010853.000|TR0|don't think the Civil Rights legislation 
20101230010853.000|20101230010855.000|TR0|is authoritarianism.  But I probably hold 
20101230010855.000|20101230010857.000|TR0|a different view.
20101230010857.000|20101230010859.000|TR0|
20101230010859.000|20101230010901.000|TR0|I think the biggest problem that we face 
20101230010901.000|20101230010903.000|TR0|is the intersection of money and politics. 
20101230010903.000|20101230010905.000|TR0| And that takes something to clean that up 
20101230010905.000|20101230010907.000|TR0|as oppose to the filibuster rule because 
20101230010907.000|20101230010909.000|TR0|it's been around for a while. Like I say, 
20101230010909.000|20101230010911.000|TR0|they've reduced it.  If they want to 
20101230010911.000|20101230010913.000|TR0|reduce it some more or do something or, 
20101230010913.000|20101230010915.000|TR0|quote, "reform it," I don't have a problem 
20101230010915.000|20101230010917.000|TR0|with that.  I just don't think that's one 
20101230010917.000|20101230010919.000|TR0|of the major problems we're faced with 
20101230010919.000|20101230010921.000|TR0|right now.
20101230010921.000|20101230010923.000|TR0|
20101230010923.000|20101230010925.000|TR0|SPITZER:  Can I just -- James, look, I 
20101230010925.000|20101230010927.000|TR0|agree with you.  If we can eliminate the 
20101230010927.000|20101230010929.000|TR0|influx of money and politics, I'm with you 
20101230010929.000|20101230010931.000|TR0|100 percent, that's more important than 
20101230010931.000|20101230010934.000|TR0|the filibuster.  The reason I'm raising 
20101230010934.000|20101230010936.000|TR0|the filibuster now is because one week 
20101230010936.000|20101230010938.000|TR0|from today, January 5th, when Congress 
20101230010938.000|20101230010940.000|TR0|comes back, the Senate will have that 
20101230010940.000|20101230010942.000|TR0|once-every-year opportunity to redefine 
20101230010942.000|20101230010944.000|TR0|its rules.
20101230010944.000|20101230010946.000|TR0|
20101230010946.000|20101230010948.000|TR0|And so I think --
20101230010948.000|20101230010950.000|TR0|
20101230010950.000|20101230010952.000|TR0|CARVILLE:  I understand, I understand.
20101230010952.000|20101230010954.000|TR0|

20101230010956.000|20101230010958.000|TR0|that resides within the Senate.  And the 
20101230010958.000|20101230011000.000|TR0|Senate is inherently an anti-democratic 
20101230011000.000|20101230011002.000|TR0|body.  The House is meant to reflect the

20101230011004.000|20101230011006.000|TR0|Senate is intended to be a clogging point

20101230014026.000|20101230014028.000|TR0|
20101230014028.000|20101230014030.000|TR0|SPITZER:  He's one of the greatest 
20101230014030.000|20101230014032.000|TR0|American tennis players in the last 
20101230014032.000|20101230014034.000|TR0|decade.  He attended Harvard, represented 
20101230014034.000|20101230014037.000|TR0|the U.S. in the 2008 Olympics, has won 10 
20101230014037.000|20101230014039.000|TR0|singles career titles.  But James Blake's 
20101230014039.000|20101230014041.000|TR0|story is really one of survival.
20101230014041.000|20101230014043.000|TR0|

20101230014045.000|20101230014047.000|TR0|broke his neck.  That same year shingles 
20101230014047.000|20101230014049.000|TR0|left half his face paralyzed and he lost

20101230014754.000|20101230014756.000|TR0|percent of parliamentarian seats allotted 
20101230014756.000|20101230014758.000|TR0|to women.  So we've been responsible for 
20101230014758.000|20101230014800.000|TR0|increasing that.  We've been responsible

20101230014802.000|20101230014804.000|TR0|true.  But there still is not -- not as 
20101230014804.000|20101230014806.000|TR0|many children in school as there were even 
20101230014806.000|20101230014808.000|TR0|when the Soviets were there.
20101230014808.000|20101230014810.000|TR0|
20101230014810.000|20101230014812.000|TR0|PARKER:  So if we do leave Air Force, what

20101230014816.000|20101230014818.000|TR0|JONES:  I think things won't be as good 
20101230014818.000|20101230014820.000|TR0|for women, but things are going backwards 
20101230014820.000|20101230014822.000|TR0|for women now.  A lot of rules have been

20101230014830.000|20101230014832.000|TR0|the gains they had made.
20101230014832.000|20101230014834.000|TR0|

20101230014836.000|20101230014838.000|TR0|rights, after all, are nothing but humans 
20101230014838.000|20101230014840.000|TR0|rights.  The right to move around, the 
20101230014840.000|20101230014843.000|TR0|right to have a job, all those things that 
20101230014843.000|20101230014845.000|TR0|men take for granted as their human rights 
20101230014845.000|20101230014847.000|TR0|are what we refer to when we talk about 
20101230014847.000|20101230014849.000|TR0|women's rights.

20101230014853.000|20101230014855.000|TR0|exercising her rights now is doing so with

20101230014859.000|20101230014901.000|TR0|brothers.  So what we're really talking 
20101230014901.000|20101230014903.000|TR0|about losing here is not women's rights, 
20101230014903.000|20101230014905.000|TR0|but the rights of all progressive people.

20101230014909.000|20101230014911.000|TR0|just about what's going to happen to
